p: Stigma has some strength similarities to “prejudice”, according to work by Allport (1958) [ 3]. The differences between the research traditions of stigma and prejudice have more to do with different subjects of interest rather than any real conceptual difference [ 12]. In fact, stigma research has traditionally emphasized the study of people with unusual conditions and visible differences (for example, facial disfigurement, HIV/AIDS, short stature, and mental illness) [ 12]. Stigmatization usually leads to discrimination [ 12, 13]; consequently, discrimination brings unequal behaviors from the collectivity and the society, convoying high levels of individual stress and significant health disparities [ 14]. In their research, Dovidio et al. [ 15] (2010) focused on three stigmatized groups (blacks, sexual minorities, and people suffering obesity), underlining that stigmatization is related to lower and poorer health levels. Kowalczuk et al. (2018) [ 16] also highlighted the existence of a horizontal discrimination in such occupational sectors, which typically offer lower rates of wages, and where women are frequently over-represented.
